@bridge_lulu Eligibility is based off of the existing Child Tax Credit rules, which is for individuals under 17 (or, in other words, 16 and under).  This is not how I would have done it (I would have included 17yo) but this is unfortunately the accurate interpretation of what is in the bill.

@MLJenne1975 You will not be required to repay the tax credit, nor will other future credits/refunds be reduced as a result of you receiving the credit. This is a brand new 2020 tax credit that the IRS is paying now instead of when you would normally file next April.

@EvolvingNation @ResisterDoggie Yes and that money is required to be spent to cover employee wages, salaries and benefits. In any case, your original assertion was trillions in corporate bailouts and now you're talking about $46 billion in payments to cover wages.  Those are very different things.

@EvolvingNation @ResisterDoggie ...the $500 billion in loans to impacted industries requires the companies be prohibited from conducting stock buy-backs, subject to public disclosure laws and have to pay the government back for the loan.  It is not, as you said, trillions in corporate bail outs.

@EvolvingNation @ResisterDoggie I'm not sure what you are quoting, but it is not accurate. The bill provides $560 billion directly to individuals, $350 billion in loans for small businesses, $340 billion for state/local govs, expanded unemployment benefits, more than $100 billion for public health needs...

@EvolvingNation @ResisterDoggie Sir, I didn't vote for trillions in corporate bailouts. If you have a suggestion for the President, I would be happy to pass it along for you, but I am working to get information to everyone about the most recent bill. I'm not interested in partisan politicking of the pandemic.
